Subject: Re: [neat] Adding only feed-forward connections
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=29390171; y=LHuWd4hSB5L1HcZMelbr7zIf7za-Gw4kxQFhY-gmJ0Pii2TwFVWFJTAFuSM

Hey, sorry to bring up this topic again, I was pretty much offline the
when it was actively discussed, but I thou

Ah, I see. Yes, sticky. Funny how stuff you implement turn out to have
implications far beyond what you realize. I was happy to find a method of
guaranteeing "no recursions" which I could implement in two minutes...

A static method (average or incremental like Ian mentions in the previous
mail) is far easier to crossover than a dynamic method (based on node
analysis). With the static method, any two networks can be crossed and all
connections will be valid. With the dynamic method, each connection will
be suspect, this could lead to two networs being genetically "incompatible";

Say network A re-orders node 1 but network B keeps it in it's original order.

On crossing A and B, connections to and from 1 must potentially be deleted
to avoid them being recurrent. While this is straight forward, though
costly, it could adversly effect evolvability.

So the questions are;
1. How much evolvability is lost by using a static method?
2. How many CPU cycles are lost by using the dynamic method?
3. How much evolvability is lost by using the dynamic method?

My guess is that the static method, being so extremely cheap, makes it the
better candidate when CPU time is limited. 

I'd also guess that the dynamic method might come out on top if the number
of generations instead are the limit (in effect, ignoring the cost of the
algorithm).

Thanks for listening ;)

cheers,
mattias

> You could have a sequence like this:
> 
> starting topology:
> A[0.0] -> C[1.0]
> B[0.0] -> C[1.0]
> 
> A[0.0] -> D[0.5] -> C[1.0]
> A[0.0] -> D[0.5] -> E[0.75] -> C[1.0]
> A[0.0] -> D[0.5] -> E[0.75] -> F[0.875] -> C[1.0]
> 
> B[0.0] -> G[0.5] -> C[1.0]
> B[0.0] -> H[0.25] -> G[0.5] -> C[1.0]
> B[0.0] -> I[0.125] -> H[0.25] -> G[0.5] -> C[1.0]
> 
> I don't think your scheme would allow any recurrent connections, but it
> would disallow several valid connections such as E[0.75] -> G[0.5].
